sect1.title: Mounting virtual kernel file systems
sect1.para: Various file systems exported by the kernel don't exist at all on your hard drive, but are used to communicate things to and from the kernel itself.
Begin by creating directories onto which the file systems will be mounted:

screen.userinput: mount -t proc proc $LFS/proc mount -t sysfs sysfs $LFS/sys

sect1.para: Remember that if for any reason you stop working on your LFS, and start again later, it's important to check that these file systems are mounted again before entering the chroot environment, otherwise problems could occur.

screen.userinput: mount -f -t ramfs ramfs $LFS/dev mount -f -t tmpfs tmpfs $LFS/dev/shm mount -f -t devpts -o gid=4,mode=620 devpts $LFS/dev/pts
